description.narrative:

comment.narrative:
(I) No legal framework for decentralization and local government in place;
(ii) No local government baseline survey and no systems for ISD and PEM/PFM in place at local level to ensure systematic needs-identifying and planning and budgeting.

description.narrative: Promoting Inclusive access to Financial Services for the Underserved Economy

"INFUSE seeks to reduce poverty through increasing access to financail services for poor people, developing policy and legal framework on inclusive finance and facilitating the sustainability of the retail financial service providers in TL"
independent political entity
policy, planning and administration

i) Number of FSPs (Financial Service Providers) that break even (Financial Self Sufficiency [FSS]) ii) Number of MFI (Microfinance institutions) that achieved Financial break-even (FSS) iii) Number of active clients iv) Number of clients with access to secured savings v) Number of voluntary savings accounts opened and sustained within project cycle. vi) Number of Loans outstanding (disaggregated by gender) vii) Average PaR for each FSP.

comment.narrative: i) As of 2009 all FSPs have reached break even points ii) As of 2009 all MFIs have reached break even points iii) As of 2009, there were 58, 574 active clients iv) As of 2009 there were 58,574 clients who have access to secured savings v) 50% of active clients have voluntary savings accounts as of 2009 vi) There were 24,519 outstanding loans of which 74% were held by women vii) There were two MFIs that have 2% PaR and one MFI that has 9% PaR as of 2009

description.narrative: Reduce the risks of natural disasters and climate change through promoting scientific information, and strengthening national, district and community-level capacity for prevention/ mitigation, preparedness, response and recovery.

This project builds on the achievements of the “Strengthening Disaster Risk Management in Timor-Leste” project (2011-2013). It is geared towards helping the Government of Timor-Leste to strengthen its DRM capacity, enhance preparedness and reduce risks.
capital of a political entity

activity-description.narrative: Support Government of TImor-Leste to strengthen its DRM capacity, enhance preparedness and reduced risk.

description.narrative: Social Protection, Land Housing and Community Amenities - disaster prevention and preparedness

1. The DRM policy framework developed based on analysis of men and women’s needs, and reflect strategies appropriate to men’s and women’s requirements. 2. National consultation processes at all levels and with all partners draw on gender analysis and include women’s organizations and networks. 3. Public finance mechanism for DRM/DRR developed. Greater awareness among key government staff on women’s needs and how to address them effectively, with adequate financial provision. 4. Quality and quantity of information available in the portal, number of data cards entered into the database system, and number of key users of portal disaggregated by gender. 5. Number of men and women participated in / benefited from identification and implementation of mitigation projects 6. Number of gender-sensitive community preparedness plans developed with equal participation of men and women 7. Comprehensive EWS assessment report include gender analysis 8. NDOMG to receive, interpret and disseminate EW 9. SOPs/plans/protocols and procedures available for EWS and address gender specific needs 10. Early recovery framework/policy developed based on needs 11. Assessments and information management systems that recognize the different needs of women and men 12. Number of plans and guidelines on early recovery prepared and available through effective engagement of women’s networks and other civil society representatives

comment.narrative: 1. DRR Policy (2008-2013) in place. Demand for DRM Act high recognizing that there is a need to integrate a gender perspective as guiding principle for DRRM in Timor-Leste. However, resources and practical operational systems at the central, decentralized district and community levels are still lacking. 2. No gender analysis exists in Timor-Leste on DRM/DRR 3. Demand for public finance system for DRM/DRR exists 4. DRM Portal and data base already in place but need enhancement 5. No contingency plan and regular simulations at district level 6. Lack of awareness regarding hazard mitigation at the community level 7. No local-level mitigation project with focus on women empowerment 8. Weak preparedness planning at the community level 9. Weak/inadequate meteorological observation system 10. Lack of adequate hardware and software for receipt, interpretation of early warning 11. Institutional arrangements or chain of command for early warning; roles and responsibilities and protocols not defined 12. EW communication/ dissemination plans/protocols/SOP yet to be developed 13. NDMD conducts post disaster damage observation and need assessment that is neither multi-sectoral, nor inclusive, and comprehensive.

1. Finalise the DRM policy through multi-stakeholder consultation including women networks. 2. Finalise the DRM legislation through multi-stakeholder consultation including women networks 3. Public finance system for DRM/DRR strengthened. 4. Provide technical, financial and administrative support to MSS, e.g. in attending high-level events and organizing IDDRR 5. Provide technical, equipment and supply support to up to 4 DDOCs 6. Capacities for reducing vulnerability of housing stocks enhanced. 7. Meteorological observation improved. 8. Early recovery policy and plans developed

description.narrative: Strengthening The Resilience of Small Scale Rural Infrastructure and Local Government Systems to Climate Variability and Risk

To strenghthening awareness of community on the climate change related and the small scale infrastrucuture and local government system to climate variabilty and risk in three Districts Ermera, Liquica and Baucau.

1. Number and type of stakeholders served by the multi-sector knowledge sharing and policy influencing platform of MCIE (; 2. Number of evidenced-based climate change risk/vulnerability assessment reports and policy recommendation documents, timely disseminated through the knowledge sharing and policy influencing platform 3. #of sectors which have endorsed MCIE's national climate change framework and strategy, and which have subsequently translated and/or integrated climate risks in key sector policies (4 sectors) 4. No of climate change vulnerability guidelines developed under the project are accepted by MSA as integral part of local planning and budgeting process (yes/no) 5. Number of sub-districts which use climate change vulnerability assessments and CC adaptation activity identification guidelines/tools as integral part of the local development and planning and budgeting process 6. # of (districts) engineering and contractor staff in focus Districts with a solid understanding of climate-induced risks to small scale infrastructure works and of possible adaptation and mitigation measures (design, construction, maintenance) 7. Number of Local Administrations (Districts and Sucos) which invest in climate resilient small rural infrastructure works, including complementary soil and land management measures as integral part of the local infrastructure development process 8. # of people benefiting from climate resilient small scale infrastructure works which are constructed in accordance with climate resilient design in the three project focus Districts 9. Number of Hectares of complementary soil and land management measures in 3 districts (target 5,000)

comment.narrative: 1. 16 multi-lateral and international organizations comprise an existing Climate Change Adaptation Working Group chaired by and 0 participation of policy makers from line agencies. 2. 0 evidence-based climate change risk / vulnerability assessment and policy recommendation documents shared through the platform. 3. 0 sectors endorsed MCIE’s National Climate Change Framework and Strategy as such Framework and Strategy does not exist yet 4. 0 climate change vulnerability guidelines developed as integral part of local planning and budgeting process under MSA. 5. 0 sub-districts use climate change vulnerability assessments and CC adaptation as integral part of the local development and planning and budgeting process 6. 0 Engineering staff and contractors at district level have very little understanding of requirements for climate resilient infrastructure development. 7. 0 local administrations which invest on climate resilient small rural infrastructure works, including complementary soil and land management measures as integral part of the local infrastructure development process 8. 0 people benefitting from climate resilient small scale infrastructure works which are constructed in accordance with climate resilient design in the three project focus municipalities 9. 0 hectares of land have administered complementary soil and land management measures in the target Administrative Posts.

1. At least 5 stakeholders identified for coordination and collaboration of climate change adaptation technical working group of MCIA. 2. At least 2 evidence-based climate change risk/vulnerability assessment reports disseminated through the Climate Change Adaptation Technical Working Group. 3. At least 4 sectors endorsed MCIE’s national climate change framework and strategy 4. Climate change vulnerability guidelines developed under the project are accepted by MSA as integral part of local planning and budgeting process. 5. At least eight Administrative Posts of focus municipalities use climate change vulnerability assessments and CC adaptation activity identification guidelines/tools as integral part of the local development and planning and budgeting process 6. At least 100 district level technical staff, engineers and EVAS members have solid understanding of climate-induced risks and related climate resilient infrastructures and CCA measures. 7. At least 3 municipalities invest in climate resilient small rural infrastructure works and design and BoQ of 12 pilot projects completed to be implemented in 2016 8. At least 68,000 people benefitted from climate resilient small scale infrastructure in three focus municipalities 9. At least 5,000 hectares of complementary soil and land management measures in 3 municipalities.

1. Knowledge sharing and coordination mechanisms among the 16 stakeholders of MCIE led multi-sector platform - Climate Change Adaptation Technical Working Group identified including for Centre for Climate Change and Biodiversity of Timor Leste and SEARCA Timor Leste Chapter leading to national level discussions on the climate change issues. 2. 3 evidence based climate change risk/ vulnerability assessment reports and policy recommendation documents disseminated at national and sub-national levels has increased the awareness on the climate risks on small scale rural infrastructure among the policy makers and multi sectoral stakeholders: a. Climate Vulnerability and Capacity Assessment conducted in 8 Administrative Posts of 3 municipalities finalized and disseminated to a wide range of stakeholders at national level, at local level and through Climate Change Adaptation Technical Working Group. b. Secondary data findings on the present status of the climate change impact and risk on small scale rural infrastructure disseminated at the national and sub-national level c. Policy gap analysis and recommendations to the MCIE disseminated to the multi-stakeholder platform at the national level
3. 0 because MCIE does not have National Climate Change Framework and Strategy yet
4. Climate change vulnerability guidelines developed under the project were accepted and mainstreamed into MSA’s local planning and budgeting process in 2014 resulting in successful completion of 11 pilot climate resilient small scale infrastructures in 10 sucos of 6 Administrative Posts in 3 focus municipalities.
5. 6 Administrative Posts in 3 municipalities used climate change vulnerability assessment and CC adaptation identification guidelines and tools disseminated during CVCA and CAMP activities as an integral part of the local development and planning and budgeting process
6. 71 district level technical staff (2015) and 10 local contractors (among 106 contractors trained in 2014) trained and

description.narrative: The DARDC comprises a joint investment by the Gov of TL and the WB to upgrade and strengthen the climate resilience of the road infrastructure linking Dili to the capitals of Aileu and Ainaro Districts.
capital of a political entity

activity-description.narrative: knowledge and understanding of local drivers of climate induced disasters enhanced, and consequent impacts on economic infrastructure better understood and available to policy makers, planners and technical staff

description.narrative: first-order administrative division

activity-description.narrative: knowledge and understanding of local drivers of climateinduced disasters enhanced, and consequent impacts on economic infrastructure better understood and available to policy makers, planners and technical staff

description.narrative: first-order administrative division

activity-description.narrative: knowledge and understanding of local drivers of climate induced disasters enhanced, and consequent impacts on economic infrastructure better understood and available to policy makers, planners and technical staff

description.narrative: Social Protection, Land Housing and Community Amenities - disaster prevention and preparedness

1. No. of target institutions with increased capacity for climate and disaster risk management, planning, budgeting and delivery at the national and sub-national level. 2. No. of targeted institutions with increased adaptive capacity to reduce risks of and response to climate variability. 3. No. of staff trained on technical CCA and DRM themes, disaggregated by gender. 4. Type and no. of recommendations to sector policies, strategies, and plans for climate change adaptation and DRM that specifically address needs of women. 5. Increase in amount of funds delivered on climate risk reduction measures at the sub-national/district level. 6. % of women benefited from community-level climate risk reduction measures. 7. Risk reduction and awareness activities introduced at local level, including: (i) EWS; (ii) improved resilience of agriculture systems; (iii) Erosion control/sustainable land and water management. 8. No. of households engaged in climate resilient land use methods and livelihoods disaggregated by gender. 9. Coverage of land with changed land use conducive to landscape stability, protecting livelihoods and physical infrastructures against climate hazards risk and disasters. 10. % of households that demonstrate an awareness between improved land use and food security/disaster mitigation through their livelihoods-disaggregated by gender.

comment.narrative: 1. Capacity for climate and disaster risk planning, budgeting and delivery at the national and sub-national level is limited 2. MSS, NDMD, DDMCs and other institutions have limited capacity to reduce risks and respond to climate variability. 3. Few staffs and community leaders have received comprehensive technical training on CCA and DRM themes. 4. Sector policies strategies and plans do not explicitly include climate change adaptation and DRM, and do not specifically address the needs of women concerning climate change and DRM. 5. Few measures for community-level disaster mitigation are currently implemented through DDMCs/district disaster focal points. 6. Women are rarely direct beneficiaries of measures for community-level disaster prevention and preparedness. 7. Few households currently benefit from risk reduction and awareness activities. 8. Few households have access to resilient livelihoods and methods 9. No Early Warning Systems (EWS) are currently in place. 10. No watershed management plans do exist. 11. Currently land left behind in shifting, slash-and-burn agriculture are left to recover without intervention and are a major source of vulnerability for communities and the road. 12. Current understanding of the links between land use and livelihoods, food and nutrition security and disasters is low.

1. Office space secured in Dili, Ainaro and Aileu and PMU for DARDC/DRM-2 established. 2. Inception Report completed and submitted on time. 3. All staff recruited. 4. Service provider recruited to review DRR/DRM/CCA training materials at INAP, conduct ToT and training of stakeholders for DARDC project. 5. National DRM policy and institutional roles extended to address climate change and disaster risk reduction measures. 6. Consultants recruited to develop a top-up grant system to local DRM institutions and local administrations for increased finance of disaster prevention and -preparedness activities as well as general resilience measures. 7. Model Early Warning Systems for DARDC region designed and establishment of systems initiated. 8. First watershed level and community-based DRR/CCA project designed with Ministry of Agriculture and Fisheries (MAF) and implementation initiated. 9. Consultant recruited to support MAF with development of watershed management plans.

description.narrative: Second National Communication to the UNFCC

The project will support the Country of Timor-Leste to Develop it’s second National Communication (SNC) to the Conference of the Parties (CoP) under the United Nations Framework Convetion on Climate Change (UNFCCC)
independent political entity

activity-description.narrative: Support Gov of Timor-Leste to Prepared the Second Report to UNFCC

description.narrative: Social Protection, Land Housing and Community Amenities - disaster prevention and preparedness

1. MSS, NDMD, DDMCs, and INAP have increased adaptive capacity to reduce risks of and respond to climate variability (Outcome 1). 2. No. of staff and community leaders with increased technical knowledge and enhanced capacities to respond to CCA and DRM themes, disaggregated by gender. 3. Type and no. of climate and disaster responsive sector policies, strategies, and plans that specifically address needs of women. 4. Increase in amount of funds delivered on climate risk reduction measures at the sub-national/district level (Outcome 2) 5. % of women benefited from community-level climate risk reduction measures. 6. Number of households benefitting from risk reduction and awareness activities introduced at local level, including: (i) EWS; (ii) improved resilience of agriculture systems; (iii) Erosion control/sustainable land and water management. 7. No. of households engaged in climate resilient land use methods and livelihoods disaggregated by gender. (Outcome 3) 8. % of land with changed land use conducive to landscape stability, protecting livelihoods and physical infrastructures against climate hazards risk and disasters. 9. % of households that demonstrate an awareness between improved land use and food security/disaster mitigation through their livelihoods-disaggregated by gender.

comment.narrative: 1. MSS, NDMD, DDMCs and INAP have limited capacity to reduce risks and respond to climate variability. 2. Few staff and community leaders have received basic knowledge on CCA and DRM themes and no comprehensive technical training provided on CCA and DRM themes. 3. Sector policies strategies and plans do not explicitly include climate change adaptation and DRM, and do not specifically address the needs of women concerning climate change and DRM. 4. DDMCs/district disaster focal points have limited funds which covers operational cost and immediate disaster response measures. 5. Less than 5 % of women directly benefiting from community-level disaster prevention and preparedness measures. 6. Few households currently benefit from risk reduction and awareness activities. 7. few households having access to resilient livelihoods and methods, the current Score is 2 8. 0% of the land degraded by shifting and slash-and-burn agriculture are restored and recovered using stabilization methods and watershed management approaches. 9. Negligible % of households at the community level of demonstrating understanding of the links between land use and livelihoods, food and nutrition security and disasters.

1. Organizational strategy to strengthen INAP’s capacity to deliver training on DRM and Climate Change adaption developed. 2. 200 staff trained at INAP through ToT and training of stakeholders for DARDC project with 50% women benefiting. 3. National DRM policy and institutional roles extended to address climate change and disaster risk reduction measures and gender sensitive recommendations. 4. A top-up grant system designed to enable local DRM institutions and local administrations for increased finance of disaster prevention and -preparedness activities as well as general resilience measures. 5. Women’s groups formed at suco and aldeia level which are able to apply for DRM funding. 6. Model Early Warning Systems for DARDC region designed and piloted in at least 4 sub-districts benefiting at least 5,000 households. 7. At least 10% of target households engage in climate resilient land use methods and livelihood 8. At least 5% of degraded land is restored through the first watershed level and community-based DRR/CCA project designed with Ministry of Agriculture and Fisheries (MAF) and implementation initiated. 9. At least 10% households surveyed confirm a clear link between resource management and resilience of livelihoods and physical infrastructure assets.

1. 0 trainings delivered 2. 0 staff trained at INAP because the procurement process to initiate the DRM Training manual review for INAP has not concluded yet. 3. Draft DRM Policy which includes gender and climate change aspects was submitted to MSS and is awaiting Council of Ministers’ approval. 4. Procurement process for a consultant based on a ToR agreed with MSS to develop a top-up mechanism for the national regional funding scheme for grants that will include DRR/DRM/CCA activities into regional planning and funding schemes has reached final stages. 5. Not achieved because the DRM financing options have not been agreed yet. 6. 0 households have benefited but 4 model Early Warning Systems were designed for floods, landslides, fires and strong winds in DARDC districts (Aileu, Ermera, Manufai and Ainaro) and four communities were selected for testing of the EWSs. 7. 0% of target households engage in climate resilient land use methods 8. 0% degraded land is restored but Joint Inspection conducted by MAF/MSS/UNDP teams identified: a. 10 locations for reforestation and 6 locations for the introduction of agro-forestry as DRM/DRR measures and additional 188 locations were identified for building of check dams and 20 locations for construction of dew ponds in Aileu. b. Five sites for reforestation activities and 160 locations have been identified for the construction of check dams and four locations for dew ponds. 9. 10% of target households indicated knowledge on the linkage between resource management and resilience of livelihoods and physical infrastructure assets through an extensive socialization programme and community consultations on EWS within the municipalities of Ainaro, Emera, Manufahi and Aileu, awareness has been raised among the communities on EWSs, watershed management approaches and the DARDC project interventions.

description.narrative: 1. Percentage of Districts/Municipalities which meet MC/MP measured through annual evaluations 2. Percentage of Districts/Municipalities develop and approves local development plans and budget each years 3. MIS system in use and provides direct input to management strategies and decisions 4. Percentage of suco plans updated and included in overall district planning framework 5. Percentage of suco councils able to provide effective oversight of local development initiatives 6. Revised DSF II approved 7. Revised PEM/PFM procedural framework approved 8. Availability of functional PBGS (PBGS is established and operational by end of 2012) 9. Revised capacity development strategy approved 10. Percentage of district capacity assessment completed (3-4 assessment completed by 2013) 11. Gender issues considered in all new policies and strategies

comment.narrative: 1. MC performance system operational in 10 Districts/Municipalities but no PM system in place 2. No integrated planning processing linking various levels 3. No MIS in place 4. Suco plans prepared but not integrated in overall district planning 5. Outdated road map for local governance reform 6. Incomplete and contradictory PEM/PFM framework for local level 7. No capacity assessment done at the local level and no capacity development strategy in place 8. No gender mainstreaming strategy in place
